text:
Hello everyone I'm a trainer Ria, and
in today's lesson we will learn about
the word 'enough'

Now firstly, you must remember what the definition is of
enough,  enough simply  means that there is a

necessary degree of strength or sufficient
strength,  let me write that down for you
necessary degree of strength. I'll explain this to  by using an example, for example - I'm making myself a lovely

cup of tea and I want quite 2 teaspoons
of sugar in my cup, now when I look into

the sugar pot,  I find that there's almost 2
teaspoons, now I find that, that is enough
for me, right?  So, to make a lovely cup of tea, I will pour out all the sugar into my cup, mix

it up and drink, right...so that much sugar was enough
for me. If it was only one teaspoon of

sugar I wouldn't have liked my tea..
so to you have something as

enough would mean that it is
sufficient enough for  you or there is a
necessary degree of strength

Let's look at 'enough' with different
parts of speech

firstly let's look at adjectives, the
first thing that you need to remember is

the adjective will come before enough in
a sentence.....
let's look at a sentence right now.  I'm old enough to vote

explaining this is in an example - I've got a
cousin who have just turned 18 and she

is very eager to vote or maybe she's very
eager to obtain a driving licence. Now if

she was 17 years of age she would not
have been able to vote or she would not

have been able to obtain a driving
licence. Since  she has just turned 18, she

is at the  right age the legal age to
obtain a license or to vote. So that is how

we will use enough in the 
sentence .... you use the adjective first...

I'm old and then you add the word enough
to vote ... explaining enough in the

second sentence with an adjective. She is
smart enough to decide for herself. Say  in a

situation where a girl is going through
a lot of problems in a relationship and

she maybe she has enough intellect to
decide for herself she knows what is

better for herself and she doesn't need
anybody's advice or anybody's help so

she is smart enough to decide what she's
about to do or what she should decide on

that relationship. So, in this sentence as
usual  you will put the adjective before enough, she is

smart enough to decide for herself,  she has
suffcient intellect to decide about the

matter. Now looking at different parts
of speech
which is adverb, please remember that an adverb is used to modify a verb

in this sentence again you will have to
remember that an Adverb  will come before

before the word enough.  She's running
quickly enough to reach on time.  Now
running is the verb, okay... to modify running you have the word quickly and after that

we have the word enough now somebody 
has to reach somewhere on

time maybe she's running after the bus
to catch the bus quickly enough, okay so..

that she can reach her destination on
time now if she's running at a

slower.... at a slower pace, would she be
able to reach reach the bus or

probably hang on to the buss 
or catch the train no she has to she

has to run quickly enough or rapidly
enough so that she can actually

actually catch the bus and that will
take her to her destination so I will explain

this part of this sentence, running is
the verb and quickly  that modifies

the verb which is the adverb and she was
running

quickly enough it means with sufficient
speed. Looking at the word in

another sentence,  The stock
market is rising steadily enough after
the crash. Now there's a market crash and after that usually there is not enough

speed  on how the market
actually climbs, but in this sentence we

are seeing  that the stock market actually
is rising very very steadily, okay. There's

so much hope with the stock market. The
stock market is rising, rising being the

verb, steadily... it is rising steadily....
at the same speed so that is an adverb
this describes how it is rising and enough means with enough or sufficient speed

Now, let's look at another  part of  speech,
which is known a Noun
Noun is a naming word. So,  enough plus a noun...Now, please remember with the other two parts of

speech the adjective and the adverb came
before enough, but in this one enough

will come before the noun, so
let's look at the first sentence. Are there  enough

students to make a batch?  Now, in this sentence
enough  comes  before students, let me also

highlight that students are countable
nouns, countable nouns being.. for
example you can count them
one student, two students, three students five, seven, nine....okay. So, this is a countable noun. Now, let's
look at an example- Let's say that an institute is making a batch,  there are about 15

students, is that enough to make a batch?
Definitely it's not, So here  a
negative point comes in,  it is ... Are there enough students to make a batch?  So, with that

the answer would be  - There are not enough
students to make a batch.  In case there

are about 20 students then we're
definitely making a batch. The students
are enough to make

a batch. So, Are there enough students to make
a batch? Now we've got twenty... yes... there

is or there are enough... sorry about that....
there are enough students to make a

batch and another thing that you need to
remember is students is plural, it is

countable noun,  it is plural, so with the plural
noun the helping verb will also be

plural. Looking at the second sentence where it's
different. There isn't enough pasta left for
everyone. Pasta  being an uncountable noun, can you count pasta? that is an uncountable noun and
students being a countable noun

let me just write that out for you. Now in
this sentence -  There isn't enough pasta for everyone

pasta being uncountable, so we're using
enough before pasta and the helping verb

that we're using in this sentence would
be singular. This is always the case when

you're using a helping verb with
uncountable noun, okay it is always going
to be singular, on the other hand if you were using a countable noun the helping verb is going to be plural
There isn't enough pasta  left for everyone . I was making pasta the other day and it was very yummy

very very delicious, so I made quite
enough for everyone and everybody

started eating it and there wasn't
enough left.

So there was not enough left for the other
batch of visitors who came, so I would

always say -  There isn't enough pasta for
everyone, maybe I should make some more

of my lovely pasta. So, this is a 
negative sentence - There isn't enough pasta

left for everyone. I hope you
have enjoyed today's lesson, just to recap
Adjective -  Enough would come after adjective.
Same is with adverbs, but with nouns, Enough will come before the noun.
I hope you've enjoyed and I will come back with another exciting lesson, till then please take care...
